Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis based on the ultrasound findings?
This ultrasound video shows findings consistent with pulmonary edema. It depicts a hyperechoic (bright white) horizontal line in the near field moving with respiration (“lung sliding”) with vertical
extending downward from the pleural line like lasers or search lights (B lines).

Analogous to Kerley B lines on a chest radiograph, a diffuse B-line pattern suggests interstitial thickening, most often caused by a fluid collection or pulmonary edema. Lung sliding and a B-line pattern throughout excludes pneumothorax, and pleural effusions will most often appear as anechoic (black) regions in dependent areas cephalad to the diaphragm.
